0.text:
Maya: Today our guest is Kelly McGonigal.
She is an expert in body/mind relationship

5.text:
and psychology of yoga.
So, she's teaching yoga and psychology -- meditation

14.text:
-- at Stanford.
And today, she's here with us to talk about

19.text:
how to use yoga for pain relief.
So, let's welcome Kelly.

24.text:
Kelly McGonigal: Thanks, Maya. Thanks, Cliff.
As Maya mentioned, I'm a health psychologist

30.text:
and a yoga teacher, and I work a lot with
people who have chronic pain issues.

34.text:
But not a lot of people know about my own
experience with chronic pain.

38.text:
And one of the most interesting things that
has come about from writing this book is that

43.text:
-- [video skips] -- I do have chronic pain
and that I have a headache just about every

48.text:
day of my life from the last 20 years.
And the people in my life seem very kind of

53.text:
perplexed by this.
They say things like, "But it doesn't seem

58.text:
to be impacting your life." -- [video skips]
 -- and it doesn't seem to limit my life.

68.text:
-- [video skips] -- Students come up to me
and test me in class like, [in a whisper]

79.text:
"Are you in pain right now?"
And if I say, "Yes," like, [whispering] "You

82.text:
have a headache right now?
Wow!"

85.text:
Because, of course, we have this idea that
pain comes with suffering.

91.text:
And in my experience -- through yoga and meditation
 -- it's possible to have pain not completely

99.text:
go away, but to feel like you have your life
back again.

104.text:
And sometimes, the pain does go away, even
if you never knew what was causing the pain

109.text:
and nothing else seemed to work.
And this is kind of part of the mystery of

112.text:
chronic pain -- that sometimes it doesn't
go away and life gets better anyway, and sometimes

117.text:
it does go away through things that you never
thought might be the solution to healing your

122.text:
pain.
And so, I'm here today to talk to you about

126.text:
how yoga can be this kind of miracle worker,
creating unexpected healing where nothing

130.text:
else seems to work for pain.
Because most people who come to yoga for pain

134.text:
relief have tried everything else; they've
tried surgeries, shots, medications, acupuncture,

141.text:
massage, maybe a $600 office chair -- you
name it.

145.text:
'Cause when we think about heavy-hitting medical
interventions, we don't tend to think of yoga

150.text:
as being sort of the first place to go.
You know -- yoga, all that stretching, ohming,

157.text:
lying around and breathing -- maybe that'll
take the edge off the pain if you chase it

163.text:
with a Percocet, but it really, like how is
that going to help?

166.text:
And, you know, sort of joking aside, there's
a growing body of scientific evidence that

171.text:
yoga can provide profound relief for many
different types of chronic pain -- whether

176.text:
it's chronic back pain, joint pain, autoimmune
disorders, fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome,

184.text:
headaches, IBS, you name it -- if it's a chronic
pain, there's probably a study showing that

189.text:
yoga helps and that yoga helps better than
traditional medical care.

192.text:
And you may not have one of these particular
chronic pain conditions, but we all have chronic

199.text:
stress, and we all have this sort of chronic,
ordinary suffering of being a human being

204.text:
in a world that's sometimes difficult and
in a body that sometimes does not seem to

208.text:
cooperate.
And yoga helps with all of that too.

211.text:
So, I hope that you'll hear something today
that is useful, whether or not you have chronic

215.text:
pain.
So, what I want to do today is talk a little

218.text:
bit about yoga -- give you some of the latest
insights from mind/body science that's changed

224.text:
the way medicine thinks about chronic pain
and gives us a sense of why yoga might be

228.text:
so helpful for chronic pain as well as some
of the coolest findings on yoga therapy for

233.text:
pain.
And then, we'll take some questions and do

236.text:
a little practice.
So, for those of you who would like to stay,

239.text:
we'll do a practice that incorporates some
of the most gentle yoga meditation techniques.

243.text:
You don't need yoga clothes.
You don't need a yoga mat, which is good,

247.text:
because it doesn't look like anyone brought
one.

249.text:
So, if you'd like to stay for that, you already
have everything that you need.

253.text:
So, one thing I want to just start off with
is that, when I say "yoga," I'm not talking

258.text:
about sort of, you know, "power yoga" or just
the movement component.

262.text:
I'm talking about five different sets of practices
from the yoga tradition.

266.text:
There's the movement -- the exercise component
 -- but there's also breathing and meditation

271.text:
and relaxation and what I call "befriending
the body" or the practices of self-care and

277.text:
of making friends and making peace with your
body even if you have illness or injury.

283.text:
And, definitely not talking about circus yoga.
So, you don't need to be able to stand on

288.text:
your head or put your leg behind your head
or anything else that would qualify you to

292.text:
be on a yoga magazine cover.
This is really basic stuff, and there's always

297.text:
a place to start.
If you can breathe, you can do yoga.

300.text:
If you have a body, you can do yoga.
And one of the things that I try to do in

304.text:
the book was provide a true starting place,
even for people who've never done yoga before,

310.text:
and even for people who have some pretty serious,
physical limitations.

313.text:
Okay. So, I think I'll start by sharing these
three key ideas that come out of mind/body

321.text:
science that's really changed the way people
think about chronic pain.

324.text:
It may change the way that you think about
your own pain and your own stress.

328.text:
And the first is the recognition that pain
is a protective and instinctive mind/body

335.text:
response.
From Mother Nature's perspective, it's not

338.text:
a problem.
Pain is not a problem. It's actually a solution

341.text:
-- a clever solution of evolution -- to make
you care about whether or not your body is

347.text:
harmed.
It's a nice little trick to make sure that

350.text:
you stay alive and that you're motivated to
keep yourself away from physical danger.

354.text:
And it starts -- the full mind/body response
starts -- any time there is a threat to your

358.text:
body.
It could be someone punching you in the face

361.text:
or it could be pulling a muscle from an activity
or touching a hot stove.

366.text:
And you've got receptors in your skin, your
muscles, your joints, and your organs that

371.text:
live for this moment -- that have been waiting
for some kind of threat so that they can do

375.text:
their jobs -- send a message up to the brain.
And that's just the beginning of the pain

379.text:
process.
So once your pain receptors have identified

382.text:
that "not everything is okay in the world"
 -- that there is this threat to your body,

386.text:
to your safety -- that message gets sent to
the brain, and not just the area to the brain

391.text:
that many of us think of as being important
for pain.

394.text:
So yes, that message is going to be sent to
the sensory areas of the brain so that you

398.text:
have a physical sense that you are a little
bit in trouble.

402.text:
But, it also gets sent to the emotional areas
of the brain that are going to make you "not

406.text:
happy" about the fact that you are in pain.
And this is why, when we experience physical

411.text:
pain, we start to feel anxious, we start to
feel angry and feel a lot of distress.

416.text:
And that signal also gets sent to the areas
of the brain that control your attention and

421.text:
that monitor for conflict and whether or not
you've met your goals yet.

425.text:
And so, when the signal gets to these areas
of the brain, it becomes very hard to focus

429.text:
on anything else, except for the pain and
the emotions around the pain.

434.text:
So now, your mind is going to be highly focused
on solving this problem -- whatever is threatening

438.text:
your safety.
And when the mind is focused in this way,

443.text:
it prompts the body into a physiological stress
response, so that you have the energy to handle

448.text:
whatever the threat is.
So we've got a brain that's completely consumed

451.text:
now with the process of pain -- your attention,
your emotions, and your sensation -- and the

456.text:
body is going to shift into a state of stress
to help you deal with it to solve the problem.

461.text:
And you can imagine how -- from an evolutionary
perspective -- this is really useful, because

465.text:
it will allow you to protect yourself.
But, you know, if this is repetitive -- if

469.text:
this is chronic -- this is really not a great
way to live.

472.text:
And the last part of the protective pain,
mind/body response is something that most

478.text:
of us don't even realize is part of this biological
pain response.

483.text:
And that's the process of learning from injury
or from pain.

487.text:
You may have noticed the last time you experienced
a lot of pain, it was kind of sticky in your

493.text:
mind.
You kept thinking about it or maybe you wanted

495.text:
to tell the story to somebody else.
And that's a really common response to pain.

499.text:
The mind -- the brain -- is trying to grapple
with what happened so that it can learn from

503.text:
it and avoid that pain in the future.
But it means that we get very stuck on our

508.text:
painful experiences, and we may become even
more vigilant for any evidence of threat or

513.text:
pain in the body.
And at the level of the nervous system, your

517.text:
body and your brain are also trying to adapt
in a way that's going to make it easier to

521.text:
respond to the same danger or threat in the
future.

525.text:
So, for example, if you've had a back injury,
the nerves of the spine and of the back are

531.text:
going to actually get better at listening
to signs of pressure or inflammation or damage

536.text:
to the connective tissue or to the muscles.
Literally, those pain receptors are going

540.text:
to get better at listening for it.
And they're going to be more eager to send

543.text:
a signal of pain to your brain so that you
will be able to respond more quickly.

548.text:
And this way, we have a back now that is sensitized
to pain.

552.text:
And this learning process happens pretty much
with any injury or with any illness where

557.text:
the body is prepared to experience that pain
again.

562.text:
And you can kind of think of this as being
like backwards from the immune system.

565.text:
If you get a cold, you're less likely to get
that same cold again.

568.text:
Or if you have a flu type, you're less likely
to get that again.

571.text:
But with pain, once you've had a certain type
of pain, you're actually more likely to experience

576.text:
it again because of the way that the body
and the brain adapts to a pain experience.

582.text:
And then, this level of learning from our
pain shows up in one last way, which is that,

586.text:
we may try to avoid things that could re-create
this pain.

590.text:
And for people who've had very painful experience
 -- like an accident or an injury or a serious

594.text:
illness -- they may start to limit their lives
so that they're not exposed to as many dangerous

599.text:
things.
And this can have a self-perpetuating cycle

602.text:
where, the more we fear pain, the less we're
willing to do, and our lives get smaller and

607.text:
smaller.
That was my experience for awhile also.

609.text:
Okay, so this first big idea is that -- thanks
to evolution -- we have an instinctive and

615.text:
protective mind/body response that helps us
deal with real threat.

619.text:
And even though it can be annoying, it's useful.
But the second key idea to come out of research

625.text:
in the last decade is that, chronic pain doesn't
work like acute pain.

630.text:
It is not useful in the way that an acute
pain process is.

635.text:
Chronic pain is overprotective and learned,
not protective and instinctive.

640.text:
People who have chronic pain have a body and
a brain that have learned to be oversensitive

645.text:
to a particular type of pain or a part of
the pain process, because it has learned so

650.text:
well from whatever the initial injury or illness
or accident or traumatic event was.

656.text:
And there's a lot of different ways that people
with chronic pain may have learned this sort

661.text:
of over-responsiveness.
I mentioned one, which is the sensitization

665.text:
of nerves.
That is, once you have an injury and illness,

667.text:
many times, part of the healing process is
making the nervous system more likely to think

673.text:
that you are in pain.
And for some people, it goes as far as having

677.text:
ordinary, safe sensations being strongly interpreted
by the nervous system and by the brain as

684.text:
being "dangerous, unsafe, and painful."
And a classic example of that is someone who

689.text:
has back pain or maybe an old shoulder injury
or knee injury where they start to exercise

695.text:
again.
And the body interprets the very normal, safe

699.text:
-- even healing -- movements of a gentle
exercise practice as being painful and damaging.

704.text:
And that's a real experience.
The pain is not somehow in your mind.

709.text:
It's real -- and it is physiological, but
it's no longer realistic.

714.text:
It has nothing to do with actual harm that's
being created in your body.

718.text:
And this is a really key insight if you have
chronic pain that it's almost as if the body

723.text:
and the brain are lying to you about what
is safe and the state of your body and the

729.text:
state of your health.
And when the body has learned to be oversensitive

736.text:
in this way -- sort of over-learned from the
experience of pain -- it's really important

739.text:
to unlearn this process, and that's where
yoga and meditation comes in.

743.text:
It's a process of re-education.
The last key idea that's come from the pain

749.text:
research, which is the one that people tend
to resist the most, because it sounds -- well,

756.text:
it sounds both kind of discouraging and also
almost -- people have heard for so long that

762.text:
"your pain is all in your mind" or "your pain
is just psychological," that we can be a little

767.text:
resistant to hearing that, "When you have
chronic pain, emotional pain is not distinct

773.text:
from physical pain."
This is not true for all types of pain, but

778.text:
for most people with chronic pain, the brain
and the nervous system have stopped distinguishing

782.text:
between stress, anxiety, depression, grief,
anger, and something going wrong in the body

788.text:
that we need to be concerned with.
One of my favorite examples comes from research

792.text:
showing that, people who have chronic back
pain -- when they get angry -- their back

797.text:
muscles tense up, and there's inflammation
in the tissues of the back.

801.text:
And that only happens for people who have
chronic back pain.

804.text:
It's like the nervous system has associated
so many times anger and stress with that biological

811.text:
process, that it's no longer that part of
the body triggering a stress response, but

816.text:
the stress response or the emotion actually
triggers that reaction in the body.

821.text:
Kind of in the same way that if you were to
remember a -- don't do this now -- but if

827.text:
you were to remember a great sexual moment
in your life, you could trigger some very

830.text:
real changes in your body, yes? It is possible.
It turns out that chronic pain works a lot

837.text:
like that too.
And there's been some interesting research

840.text:
at Stanford showing that, even just the memory
of pain can re-create changes in the body

845.text:
that are consistent with that pain -- like
muscle tension, like inflammation, like an

851.text:
increased stress response.
And, in addition, one of the things I didn't

857.text:
mention is that, the protective pain response
that I described -- the one that is useful

861.text:
for us in most situations -- it's the same
for a physical threat as for a social threat.

866.text:
That is, the same areas of the brain are recruited,
including physical sensations of pain.

873.text:
If you have been punched in the jaw or if
you've been rejected by a loved one, when

877.text:
you're feeling lonely, you've got pretty much
the same process going on -- same regions

882.text:
of the brain activated -- as when you have
the flu.

886.text:
And that's one of the reasons why heartbreak
really, really hurts.

891.text:
We're being rejected or when you're feeling
angry at someone -- it actually hurts.

895.text:
And you can imagine, from an evolutionary
perspective, why that might be useful too.

899.text:
Because when we think about what threatens
our well-being, being separated from the tribe

904.text:
is one of the most dangerous, dangerous things
that could happen for your well-being and

908.text:
for your life.
And so, it seems like evolution has kind of

910.text:
mapped these two together.
So that when you are in emotional pain or

914.text:
particularly social pain, you're going to
use the same systems that help protect you

919.text:
when there's a physical threat.
Again, this gets very tricky with chronic

922.text:
pain, because it means that the emotions related
to social relationships -- stress at work,

928.text:
all of that -- it can reinforce the pain.
And, in fact, for people who have chronic

935.text:
pain, there's evidence that psychological
stress even further sensitizes the nervous

940.text:
system to send those threat signals up to
the brain.

942.text:
So, when you're stressed or when you're angry
or when you're lonely, it's like the whole

946.text:
nervous system is listening for more evidence
that something is wrong.

951.text:
And what all of this means is that, if you
have chronic pain, stress management is number

956.text:
one on the agenda for healing pain.
And even though it sounds kind of "woo woo"

961.text:
or fuzzy, handling stress and emotions tends
to be a lot more effective for chronic pain

968.text:
than trying to find one thing in the body
that's wrong and fixing it with surgery or

973.text:
medications.
Because with chronic pain, that one thing

977.text:
that's wrong in the body,
that was resolved or healed probably a long

981.text:
time ago, and what you're left with is this
kind of residual learning that is systemic.

986.text:
It's in the whole body, including the embodied
mind -- the nervous system, the brain.

991.text:
It's no longer just in your back muscle or
just in your knee or just in your jaw or wherever

997.text:
the pain originated.
So, I think that might be fun to share with

1005.text:
you some of the findings.
Some of you know that I'm a yoga researcher,

1011.text:
and I think it's really exciting how much
research is being done on yoga these days.

1015.text:
I want to share with you some of the findings
that might either give you a little more motivation

1019.text:
to do yoga, or that -- for those of you who
are already yoga enthusiasts -- you might

1023.text:
be able to marshal some of this evidence against
the people who are resisting yoga who might

1027.text:
benefit from it.
I've heard that you shouldn't drag people

1031.text:
to yoga, but I think sometimes data can drag
people to yoga, which is useful.

1036.text:
So there have been a number of studies in
the last couple of years showing that yoga

1040.text:
is more effective for chronic back pain than
regular exercise or standard medical care.

1047.text:
And that a very gentle yoga practice done
a couple times a week for about 30 minutes

1052.text:
a day -- some very gentle moving, breathing,
and relaxation -- actually helps people reduce

1057.text:
their need for pain medications, including
very strong pain medications like opiates.

1063.text:
As well as improving the symptoms -- the psychological
symptoms of chronic pain, like depression

1068.text:
-- as well as the physical function and the
physical pain.

1070.text:
And other studies have shown that yoga can
really change the way that the nervous system

1077.text:
responds to stress.
There's a study that just came out looking

1081.text:
at restorative yoga.
And this is a really easy way into yoga.

1084.text:
Restorative yoga -- you basically lie around
in a bunch of different positions, hugging

1088.text:
pillows and breathing.
And this study showed that people who practiced

1093.text:
restorative yoga have lower baseline levels
of inflammation.

1097.text:
And this is really key, because inflammation
 -- circulating levels of inflammation in

1101.text:
your body -- prime you to experience pain.
They sensitize the nerves so you're more likely

1105.text:
to experience pain and discomfort and swelling
and all of that.

1110.text:
And not only do they have lower baseline levels
of inflammation, but when the researchers

1115.text:
expose them to a stressful situation, they
have less of an inflammatory response to that

1120.text:
stress.
So things were good from the get-go.

1123.text:
And when you stress them out, that stress
response doesn't look so unhealthy.

1127.text:
It certainly doesn't look like the kind of
stress response that really reinforces and

1131.text:
makes pain worse.
Another key study that came out recently was

1137.text:
looking at people who have an autoimmune disorder,
which tends to be characterized by high levels

1142.text:
of stress response in the body -- sympathetic
nervous system activation.

1146.text:
And they found that a short yoga program actually
reduced baseline levels of sympathetic nervous

1152.text:
system activity in a population where that
can be one of the key factors in determining

1157.text:
whether you have a good day, a bad day, a
good week, a bad week -- whether you can get

1161.text:
out of bed or not.
And again, there's a really simple practice,

1164.text:
but one that included a little bit of breathing,
a little bit of relaxation, a little bit of

1169.text:
movement.
And then, there are all the studies looking

1172.text:
at meditation as a kind of a special form
of yoga -- a special -- this sort of unique

1180.text:
way to deal with pain, by teaching you how
to choose the focus of your attention and

1184.text:
also how not to panic when you feel pain or
a distressful emotion.

1189.text:
And there have been studies looking at -- you
may think of as kind of "meditation masters"

1193.text:
-- people who've been doing it for a long
time.

1195.text:
And in these studies, they exposed the meditators
to some pretty serious pain, maybe thermal

1201.text:
stimulation, a point where this is not subjective
whether this hurts -- there's some real tissue

1206.text:
damage happening; this hurts.
And they looked at what happens in the brain

1211.text:
of the meditator when they're being exposed
to this subjective, painful stimulation.

1216.text:
And meditators appear to be able to literally
shut down parts of the pain processing, particularly

1222.text:
the emotional aspect of pain processing that
makes you feel like there's something really,

1227.text:
really terrible about what's happening in
your body.

1230.text:
And I started this talk by mentioning that
I have a headache almost every day, and yet,

1235.text:
I don't really have any suffering.
It's just kind of there.

1239.text:
And I think that's a big part of what's going
on with some of these meditators that you

1242.text:
can be receiving part of the pain signal,
and yet, it doesn't launch this full, overprotective,

1248.text:
learned response of the brain freaking out
and the body freaking out and having to solve

1253.text:
it as a problem.
There's even a study published a couple months

1257.text:
ago that took people who weren't expert meditators,
introduced them to mindfulness meditation

1264.text:
and a little bit of gentle yoga movement and
relaxation.

1267.text:
And before and after this intervention, they
took pictures -- 3-dimensional pictures -- of

1272.text:
the brain.
And they were particularly interested in the

1275.text:
areas of the brain that detect threat and
produce the stress response.

1280.text:
And they found that, after this 8-week intervention,
the participants actually had decreased neuronal

1286.text:
density in the regions of the brain that interpret
threat and produce a stress response.

1291.text:
It is in a way like the brain was getting
smaller.

1294.text:
And this is one of the first studies that's
been able to show this, even though there

1298.text:
are lots of studies showing that chronic pain
and chronic stress makes this area of the

1304.text:
brain bigger and more connected to other areas
of the brain.

1307.text:
And so, this is the first study showing that
gentle yoga and meditation can reverse that

1311.text:
process and essentially create a brain that's
more resilient to stress and less likely to

1316.text:
produce this overprotective stress response.
There's lots of other studies like this, including

1323.text:
studies that aren't directly connected to
yoga and meditation, but show that shifting

1328.text:
your focus of attention or improving your
mood can have the equivalent effect on pain

1334.text:
as a dose of morphine.
And this is what yoga practice is all about

1338.text:
-- choosing the focus of your attention and
boosting your mood a little bit.

1342.text:
I guess the last finding that there's anyone
left unconvinced is, the most recent observation

1350.text:
that meditation and gentle movement like yoga
increases neuroplasticity.

1355.text:
I'd mentioned that chronic pain is a learned
response.

1359.text:
And the solution for most people with chronic
pain is not something like surgery, but the

1365.text:
re-education process -- the re-learning.
And meditation and gentle movement increase

1370.text:
brain-derived neurotrophic factor, which is
what allows the brain to actually learn new

1375.text:
habits.
And you can actually take a brain that has

1379.text:
trained itself to over-interpret stress and
pain and become much more resilient and less

1384.text:
reactive.
And I think at this point, it might be useful

1391.text:
to open it up to some questions about yoga
or pain or anything.

1400.text:
Now, we're going to -- did you want to use
one of the other microphones for this or this

1419.text:
Q Hi. So my question is, you were talking
about the body kind of remembering an old

1428.text:
injury and being more susceptible or, you
know, triggering pain more than it would if

1435.text:
it didn't have that.
Is it site specific, meaning like, if I had

1962.text:

1967.text:
-- through standard physical care -- the

1972.text:

 -- that's when exploring these other aspects
